Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Emissions and Fate of Volatile Organic Compounds (VOCs) Emitted from Australian Wildfires during the COALA-JOEYS Campaign
Award.AbstractNarration: This RAPID project takes advantage of the ongoing participation of a US investigator in an Australian campaign to study the vegetative emissions of atmospheric compounds in pristine and in polluted conditions in New South Wales Australia, enabling the investigator to extend these efforts to study the emissions from the massive wildfires now occurring in that region. The data from this project will be evaluated in comparison to wildfire studies in the US, and help to develop a better understanding of how the chemical composition of wildfire emissions vary depending on the material burned. The results have immediate relevance to the general public, as large populations are currently being exposed to Australian bushfire smoke with unknown chemical composition.<br/><br/>The COALA-JOEYâ€™s (Characterizing Organics and Aerosol Loading over Australia - Joint Organic Emissions Year-round Study) campaign in Australia will be extended to focus on emissions from ongoing Australian wildfires. Samples will be obtained in the plumes of smoke from the fires using a proton-transfer-reaction time-of-flight mass spectrometer to identify volatile organic compounds (VOCs), including intermediate oxidation products and semivolatile VOCs. This data is expected to help resolve some of the large uncertainties in the formation of oxidized VOCs in fire plumes. In particular, the emissions of fire-related formic acid (HCOOH) are especially uncertain in Australian fires. Atmospheric HCOOH contributes to precipitation acidity and chemistry, and its sources are generally not well captured in global models. Constraining primary emissions of HCOOH and investigating secondary formation mechanisms will provide a valuable constraint on global HCOOH budgets as well as on the ultimate fate of biomass burning emissions. This project will advance the knowledge of VOC emissions from Australian wildfires, their variability and dependencies, and subsequent VOC oxidation.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Australia is a major hot-spot of global biomass burning emissions, but wildfires in this region are less well-studied compared to other (i.e., US) biomes. This RAPID project supported observations of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in Australia during the historic 2019/2020 wildfire season, colloquially called the ?Black Summer?. Field observations are used to improve our understanding of the role of fuel type, combustion conditions, and photochemical processes on the abundance and speciation of VOCs present in wildfire plumes.

A proton-transfer-reaction time-of-flight mass spectrometer (PTR-TOF-MS) was deployed to New South Wales, Australia during the COALA-2020 (Characterizing Organics and Aerosol Loading over Australia) field campaign. Back-trajectory analysis suggests that the smoke plume intersecting our site originated from fires burning near the coast of the New South Wales/Victoria border, approximately 390 km south of site. Because the fuel load in this region is primarily eucalyptus, the smoke was expected to have different characteristics than smoke in US fires.

As the plume had travelled ~8 hrs before reaching the site, we restrict our analysis to VOC species that would be minimally impacted by plume chemistry during the overnight plume transport. This leaves 15 compounds for which we examine emission factors, includes 6 compounds previously not reported for this compound, and acrolein, which has significant health impacts. We compare our derived emission factors with those from previous studies in New South Wales, Australia, western U.S. wildfires, and lab-based studies. We see unexpectedly good agreement across these biomes. A major finding is that emissions factors from non-Australian studies can effectively be used in air quality models if they?re derived from analogous but geographically separated biomes.

Finally, we examined the increase in VOC-related OH reactivity that results from long-range plume transport. OH reactivity quantifies the total amount of reactive carbon in the atmosphere. We saw OH reactivity was significantly elevated above ?typical? levels in the plume as a result of elevated levels of furans, alkenes, and aromatics, with smaller enhancements from oxygenated non-aromatic compounds. The OH reactivity this plume brought to the site nearly doubled that of the reactivity resulting from biogenic isoprene and monoterpenes at the site, suggesting large contributions to next-day ozone formation from transported VOCs.

To date, the VOC data acquired through this project has been foundational to two peer-reviewed publications. The dataset is publicly available, and expected to be used in broader future studies. Additionally, this work supported the training and education of one graduate student, and fostered new international collaboration in the atmospheric chemistry community.
